lessonCreationProcess.overview: Lessons are created incrementally using a fragment-based approach. Each lesson is broken into multiple HTML fragments (a, b, c, d, etc.) that are later concatenated into a complete lesson file. This allows for iterative review and correction during the creation process.

fragmentWorkflow.description: The creation process follows a strict iterative cycle
steps: 2. AI STOPS and waits for human review
3. Human reviews fragment A and provides feedback/corrections
4. AI makes any requested edits to fragment A
7. Repeat steps 2-6 for fragments C, D, E, etc. until lesson is complete
8. Concatenate all fragments into final lesson file
criticalRules: NEVER create multiple fragments without explicit approval
ALWAYS stop after creating each fragment
ALWAYS wait for human review before proceeding
EDIT existing fragments when changes are needed, don't rewrite
Ask for clarification if instructions are unclear

size.description: Each fragment should be manageable in size
guidelines: Not so large that review becomes overwhelming
Not so small that you have 20+ fragments

rules: Use underscores, not hyphens or spaces
Letter suffix (a, b, c, d, etc.) indicates fragment sequence
Filename matches the lesson's main filename from course-config.json

fragmentA.description: First fragment includes full HTML document setup
mustInclude: Complete <head> with meta tags, title, CSS links
Lesson header with title and lead paragraph
Table of Contents with all major sections
Comment indicating end of fragment A

fragmentBtoN.description: Middle fragments contain main content sections
mustInclude: Comment indicating start of fragment (e.g., <!-- PART B STARTS HERE -->)
Appropriate subsections, examples, and interactive demos
mustNotInclude: Body, nav, or structural opening tags

mustInclude: Comment indicating start of final fragment

tone.description: Write as an amazing instructor teaching new learners

softwareAgnostic.description: Content must work across ALL major digital art software
approach: Explain the underlying principle, not specific buttons
When showing software-specific info, include multiple programs
Use comparison tables for software differences
Focus on 'what' and 'why', not just 'how' in one app

mermaidDiagrams.when: Use for workflows, hierarchies, relationships, processes
mermaidDiagrams.requirement: Must include mermaid script in head
mermaidDiagrams.script:
<script type='module'>
  import mermaid from 'https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mermaid@10/dist/mermaid.esm.min.mjs';
  mermaid.initialize({ startOnLoad: true });
</script>
mermaidDiagrams.formatting: Ensure proper escaping of special characters in mermaid syntax

canvasInteractive.when: Use for interactive demos, visual demonstrations, hands-on examples
requirements: Each canvas must have unique ID
Include clear instructions for user interaction
Provide fallback text if canvas doesn't work

svgGraphics.when: Use for scalable illustrations, icons, diagrams
svgGraphics.benefit: Vector graphics scale perfectly on all devices

emojis.when: Use throughout for visual interest and clarity

organizationalTools: Tables for comparisons and structured data

Create, organize, and manage complex layer structures efficiently
Master all major blend modes and know when to use each
Implement non-destructive editing workflows
Composite multiple elements into cohesive artwork
Develop professional layer organization habits
Apply layer techniques to real-world painting scenarios

exercises.title: Professional Layer Organization
exercises.description: Organize a complex artwork with proper naming, grouping, and color coding

proTips: Use Ctrl/Cmd+Click on layer thumbnail to select layer contents
Alt+Click layer visibility to solo that layer
Use blend mode keyboard shortcuts (Shift+ or Shift-)
Create a 'master group' for major sections
Keep a 'backup' group with flattened versions at key stages
Use adjustment layers instead of direct color correction
Name layers as you create them, not later
Use clipping masks for contained effects

exercises.title: Palette Extraction
exercises.description: Extract and recreate a color palette from a master painting or photograph

commonMistakes: Using too many colors (lack of harmony)
proTips: Value is more important than hue - get your lights/darks right first
Limited palettes create more cohesive artwork
Add a 'mother color' (tiny bit of one color in everything) for unity
Cool colors recede, warm colors advance (use for depth)
Grays and desaturated colors make saturated colors pop
Study master paintings to learn color relationships
Test your palette in grayscale to check value structure
Sample colors from your own work to maintain consistency

commonMistakes: Forgetting to invert mask when needed
Making selections too tight (no room for refinement)
Not using Select and Mask for complex edges
Deleting masks instead of disabling them
Painting on layer instead of mask
proTips: Always use masks instead of erasing - stay non-destructive
Alt-click mask thumbnail to view mask in isolation
Shift-click mask thumbnail to disable temporarily
Use soft brushes on masks for natural edges
Refine Edge/Select and Mask is magic for hair
Save complex selections as alpha channels
Use Multiply blend mode on masks for gradual transparency
Ctrl/Cmd + click mask thumbnail to load as selection
